verses.text: And the Lord sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said to him, “There were two men in a city, one rich and the other poor.
verses.comment: Nathan confronts David by telling a parable, as is standard in the original Hebrew text.

verses.text: The rich man had very many flocks and herds,
verses.comment: Conveys the Hebrew for 'very many' (abundant), not just 'many'.

verses.text: but the poor man had nothing except one little ewe lamb, which he had bought and nourished, and it grew up together with him and with his children. It ate of his own food, drank from his own cup, and lay in his arms, and to him it was like a daughter.
verses.comment: Translates the Hebrew for 'lay in his arms' as the idiom 'lay in his arms,' not modernizing into alternate idioms.

verses.text: Now a traveler came to the rich man, and he spared his own flock and herd, to prepare a meal for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the poor man's lamb and prepared it for the man who had come to him.
verses.comment: Keeps the basic linear narrative found in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then David's anger was greatly kindled against the man, and he said to Nathan, “As the Lord lives, the man who has done this is worthy to die.
verses.comment: Translates literally 'son of death' as 'worthy to die' for readability.

verses.text: And he shall restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing and had no pity.
verses.comment: References the restitution law from Exodus.

verses.text: Nathan said to David, “You are the man! Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you out of the hand of Saul.
verses.comment: 'You are the man!' is kept direct as in Hebrew.

verses.text: And I gave you your master’s house and your master’s wives into your arms, and gave you the house of Israel and of Judah. And if that had been too little, I would have added to you much more.
verses.comment: ‘Into your arms’ (literally, into your lap) is kept literal for faithfulness.

verses.text: Why have you despised the word of the Lord, to do what is evil in his sight? You have struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and you took his wife to be your wife, and you have killed him with the sword of the sons of Ammon.
verses.comment: ‘Sons of Ammon’ for the Ammonites, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Now therefore the sword will never depart from your house, because you have despised me and taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
verses.comment: ‘Sword will never depart’ is a literal translation of the Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord: ‘Behold, I will raise up evil against you out of your own house. And I will take your wives before your eyes and give them to your neighbor, and he will lie with your wives in the sight of this sun.
verses.comment: ‘Lie with your wives’ is kept as in the original for faithfulness.

verses.text: For you did it secretly, but I will do this thing before all Israel and before the sun.’”
verses.comment: ‘Before the sun’ is a literal translation of the public nature of the act.

verses.text: David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.” And Nathan said to David, “The Lord also has put away your sin; you will not die.
verses.comment: ‘Put away your sin’ is literal, not modernized.

verses.text: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have utterly scorned the Lord, the child who is born to you shall surely die.”
verses.comment: ‘Utterly scorned’ reflects the Hebrew intensification.

verses.text: Then Nathan went to his house. And the Lord struck the child that Uriah’s wife bore to David, and it became very sick.
verses.comment: ‘Very sick’ (severely ill) is literal.

verses.text: David therefore sought God for the child, and David fasted and went in and lay all night on the ground.
verses.comment: ‘Lay...on the ground’ is a faithful rendering.

verses.text: The elders of his house stood beside him to raise him from the ground, but he was not willing, nor did he eat food with them.
verses.comment: ‘Not willing’ (he refused), as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: On the seventh day, the child died. And the servants of David were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “Behold, while the child was still alive, we spoke to him, and he did not listen to our voice. How then can we say to him, ‘The child is dead’? He may do himself harm.”
verses.comment: ‘Do himself harm’ (Heb., do evil) clarified for modern readers.

verses.text: But when David saw that his servants were whispering together, David understood that the child was dead. David said to his servants, “Is the child dead?” They said, “He is dead.”
verses.comment: Narrative voices preserved as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then David arose from the ground, washed and anointed himself, and changed his clothes. He went into the house of the Lord and worshiped. Then he went to his own house; and when he asked, they set food before him, and he ate.
verses.comment: ‘Anointed himself’ (with oil), as per Hebrew custom.

verses.text: Then his servants said to him, “What is this thing that you have done? You fasted and wept for the child while he was alive, but when the child died, you rose and ate food.”
verses.comment: Speech is rendered in direct, clear modern English.

verses.text: He said, “While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept, for I said, ‘Who knows whether the Lord will be gracious to me, that the child may live?’
verses.comment: ‘Who knows’ is a direct echo of similar language elsewhere.

verses.text: But now he is dead. Why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he will not return to me.”
verses.comment: Faithful to the existential and theological wording of the text.

verses.text: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, and went in to her and lay with her. She bore a son, and he called his name Solomon. And the Lord loved him,
verses.comment: Uses 'went in to her' as literal rendering.

verses.text: and he sent word by the hand of Nathan the prophet, and he called his name Jedidiah, because of the Lord.
verses.comment: Jedidiah means 'Beloved of the Lord'; translated name is explained in the comment.

verses.text: Now Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and took the royal city.
verses.comment: ‘Rabbah of the Ammonites’ is the literal name.

verses.text: And Joab sent messengers to David and said, “I have fought against Rabbah. Moreover, I have taken the city of waters.
verses.comment: ‘City of waters’ is retained literally, referring to the city with the water supply.

verses.text: Now therefore gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city and take it; otherwise I will take the city, and it will be called by my name.”
verses.comment: Joab’s words are rendered close to Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: So David gathered all the people together and went to Rabbah and fought against it and took it.
verses.comment: Clear narrative structure.

verses.text: He took the crown of their king from his head. Its weight was a talent of gold, and there were precious stones in it. It was placed on David’s head. He brought out a great amount of spoil from the city.
verses.comment: ‘A talent of gold’ is the literal standard weight (about 75 lbs / 34 kg).

verses.text: He brought out the people who were in it, and put them to labor with saws, iron picks, and iron axes, and made them work at the brick kilns. David did this to all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Reflects the Hebrew which is ambiguous about whether David killed or enslaved the Ammonites; rendered as ‘put them to labor’ per many major translations.
